Award.AwardTitle: UBM-Institutional: Interdisciplinary Training and Research for Undergraduates in Biological and Mathematical/Statistical Sciences at UMBC
Award.AbstractNarration: Researchers from the Department of Biological Sciences and the Department of Mathematics and Statistics at the University of Maryland Baltimore County (UMBC) will create an interdisciplinary program in biological mathematics and statistics. A key element of this program will be undergraduate students from each department working in teams under the supervision of a pair of faculty from each department to apply modern mathematical and statistical approaches to significant biological problems. The proposed research will use model and non-model organisms to investigate questions from a wide range of disciplines in biology, including physiology, cell biology, genetics, and evolution. The proposed research will require development and application of modern mathematical and statistical approaches to address questions in each research area and subsequent testing of these models in experiments. In addition, the principal investigators propose to fortify the connections between Mathematics, Statistics and Biology for all undergraduate students in these departments by revising the current curriculum to improve interdisciplinary education in existing courses and developing new courses in biomathematics and biostatistics. The principal investigators will also host faculty development workshops designed to allow current faculty to integrate more quantitative applications into core courses in the Biology major and to provide faculty in the Mathematics and Statistics Department with compelling biological problems to challenge students in their core courses. The proposed program will provide high quality interdisciplinary research training to 40 undergraduate researchers, creating a synergistic research environment for students and faculty. In addition, the proposed curriculum development, combined with faculty development and establishment of a new minor in Quantitative Biology will provide cross-disciplinary education for all undergraduates majoring in Biology, Mathematics and Statistics. Thus, students graduating from these programs will be well suited to carry out modern biological research that increasingly requires greater sophistication of quantitative approaches to enhance our understanding of biological systems.

ProgramReference.Text: PROG FOR WOMEN AND UNDERREPRESENT GROUPS

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Undergraduate Biology and Mathematics program at UMBC (http://ubm.umbc.edu/) provided broad interdisciplinary training for 47 undergraduate researchers (24 biology majors and 23 math/stat majors) and fostered a culture of interdisciplinary research across our college. Students worked in teams and were co-mentored by pairs of faculty from the departments of Biology (7 faculty) and Mathematics/Statistics (6 faculty). The program included a two year research experience for students working on active research projects of participating faculty, focusing on a wide range of disciplines in biology, including physiology, cell biology, genetics, and evolution.  Several outcomes indicate the program was highly successful in advancing knowledge and promoting STEM participation: Students gave over 40 research presentations on their work, published six peer reviewed papers (so far), generated three technical publications, and produced 10 honors theses. Over half of the participants in this program who have graduated have gone on to graduate or professional schools or obtained jobs in STEM disciplines. The project also had a significant impact on the participating departments as well as the university itself. We initiated the UBM Distinguished Speaker Series and hosted 16 eminent scholars over the past six years who gave interdepartmental seminars on their cutting edge biomathematics research. Visiting scholars also met with students and faculty in the program to advise them on ways to initiate and sustain interdisciplinary research. The Department of Biological Sciences and the Department of Mathematics and Statistics worked together to create two new minors, one in quantitative biology for students majoring in mathematics and statistics, and the other a minor in biomathematics for students majoring in biology. As part of this effort we developed a new core course, Math 355 Biomathematics.  Thus, through these new minor programs and the course, this project will have longstanding effects on the interdisciplinary education of undergraduate students for many years to come.

The Broader Impacts of this program were substantial. Through the various presentations by students and faculty at local and national meetings, the program highlighted the promise of interdisciplinary approaches to address modern biological problems and demonstrated the success of such approaches.  The project contributed substantially to the quantitative and biological training of students from underrepresented groups (of the 47 student participants, 21 were women, 3 of which were minority students). The program also contributed extensively to faculty development in interdisciplinary research and while the program is no longer active, faculty collaborations across departments have continued.  These collaborations are generating additional and important findings to address questions that lie at the interface of biology, mathematics and statistics.  Their continued collaborations are not only resulting in publications and the development of new grant proposals to continue their work, the faculty teams continue to recruit undergraduates from varied disciplines to work in their laboratories.  By all measures this program has been a resounding success. The funding provided by NSF for this project established a new culture of collaboration between our departments and created a number of interdisciplinary research projects.  The team-based system of interdisciplinary research and training generated by this program created an effective framework that faculty are likely to reuse in the future. This new culture of interdisciplinary research will allow us to continue our efforts to address complex biological problems while at the same time preparing undergraduate and graduate students for careers in biomathematics, biostatistics and fields that require a strong background in computational approaches to solve biological problems.
